title: Removing trailing commas inside object
body: Parse error. Internet Explorer has a non-standard intepretation of trailing commas. Objects will not parse at all.

title: Patch to make JS minification work
body:
I installed node-0.4.8 but was still having trouble building minified versions of D3.js:

```
Error: Cannot find module '../../UglifyJS'
```

This patch changes the relative include inside of lib/uglifyjs so compiling D3 "just works" with node as the only pre-requisite.

title: Micro-optimisation: remove arguments check.
body:
This is around 6x faster when using V8's Crankshaft as the JIT bails due to the `arguments.length` reference.  I know the `arguments.length` check is used extensively in D3 and it's nice to keep it this way for consistency, but it might be worth replacing in this case as centroid may well get "hot" e.g. when used intensively for geo visualisations.

Still, micro-optimisations are debatable and this will likely become obsolete as Crankshaft gets smarter, so take with a pinch of salt!

title: Linear and log ticks: support descending domains.
body: To do: support polylinear domains.

title: Add hierarchical edge bundling layout.
body:
Based on http://cs.stanford.edu/people/mbostock/iv/dependency-tree.html.

A nicer way to specify `outgoing` links would be good.

title: d3.svg.area: evaluate x-accessor once per element.
body:
I played with extracting `d3_svg_linePoints` but this seems simpler.  Depends on how micro-optimised you want this to be. :-)

Fixes #187.

title: Couple of tweaks to reset gravity.
body:
Firstly, when the mouse exits the area the gravity coordinates are nullified.

Secondly, if the user switches to another window, the gravity coordinates are nullified (otherwise the appropriate `mouseout` event may be missed).

title: Add d3.sum.
body: Fixes #191.  Also fixed a couple of minor typos in the min/max tests.

title: fix minor errors
body:
I'm working with a system that concatenates all the JS into one file, and it doesn't deal well with the minor syntax issues in this file. 

In particular, the lack of ';' means that each anonymous function trys to call the next:

(...d3.js...)()
(...d3.layout.js...)()

putting semicolons at the end makes JS a lot happier.

The other minor change is a trailing-comma fix that would blow up explorer - I know there's know way you'd support old explorerers, but JS compilers/minimizers balk at the trailing comma...

title: Semicolon needed after modules
body:
Modules should end with a semicolon so that they're parsed correctly even if several modules are concatenated into the same file.
Without a semicolon, JavaScript evaluates

```
a = b + c
(d + e).print()
```

as

```
a = b + c(d + e).print();
```

rather than

```
a = b + c;
(d + e).print();
```

title: Add "boid" flocking: d3.ai.boid().
body:
Includes interactive "voroboids" example!

I appreciate this may be a bit too esoteric even for inclusion in its own module.  Still, it might be useful for "arty" uses of D3. :)

I played with the idea of having `d3.ai.boids` process a whole flock of boids at once, but I think `d3.ai.boid` (singular) better represents the fact that the flocking behaviour emerges from rules applied to each individual boid.  Having said that, it might be more reusable to process a whole flock at once, and properties such as "neighbour radius" optionally be set with a function that gets applied to each boid.

Also, just realised I've used the British spellings for "neighbourRadius" and "gravityCentre"; I guess I should change that. :-)

title: Instantiating enter affects update.
body: Previously, if you instantiated the enter selection via append or insert, you'd have to re-select to unify the enter and update selection (the post-transform nodes). Now, simply by appending or inserting the entering nodes, the update selection automatically refreshes, obviating the need for a reselect. If you still want to perform actions only on the updating nodes, you can do so by performing these actions before instantiating the enter selection.

title: Simplify subclassing of hierarchy layout.
body: The subclasses can't use the same object as the parent class, because they are functions. But, there's no reason to duplicate the code that rebinds the methods onto the subclass.

title: Tweens are now optional.
body: If the tween function returns null, then no tween will be applied for the specified element. The default tween function now returns null if the start and end value are the same, thus avoiding redundant interpolation.

title: .debug()
body:
A tiny utility function to take a peek into the chain with console.log(). 

Usage: `.debug('Tag to print with the result')`

Example:

```
vis.selectAll("g.arc")
  .data(arcs(data0, data1))
  .enter()
  .debug("Data: ")
  .append("svg:path")
  .attr("d", arc)
  .debug("End of chain: ");
```

title: .attr( map ) and .attr( function() {return map} )
body:
`attr` can now take a map of name/value pairs, by calling itself recursively for each pair.
`attr` can now take a function which returns a map.

title: Add d3.svg.superformula.
body:
I followed the same pattern as d3.svg.symbol to add a d3.svg.tweenable that can interpolate simple shapes like rectangle, ellipse, circle, diamond, gear, drop. More complex shapes can be generated as they are all derived from the Superformula (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superformula).

You can see a working example here: http://christopheviau.com/var/d3_tween/index.html.

title: Add d3.scale.linear().nice().
body: Based on the Protovis implementation.  "Nices" the scale, extending the bounds of the input domain to evenly-rounded values.

title: Scatter plot.
body: I've put this in a separate pull request so it's easier to review.  It's a pretty straightforward extraction of the scatterplot code from `d3.chart.qq` though.

title: Radar chart.
body:
This also includes a fix for a problem with `d3.chart.axis`, where the intermediate ticks have the same text content as the major ones, and hence the data join is confused.

I need a nice way to transition the data lines when adding/removing axes (or perhaps axes transitions should just be dropped entirely).

I merged the axis branch into this one so I could use it, I hope that's not too confusing.  Maybe I should have submitted a pull request to your axis branch so the diff is cleaner?  Anyway, I'm sure you'll cope :)

title: heart d3 symbol
body: I know it's a super small contribution for now, but hopefully as I make the switch from protovis to d3 over the next couple months I can help with more additions....

title: Add reusable axis helper for charts.
body: It could probably be a bit more flexible but I think it'll reduce the number of lines needed to set up simple x- and y-axes.  The helper returns the entering `<g>` node so that the tick line and text can be set up appropriately.

title: Add reusable Mekko chart.
body: I thought people might like a reusable version of your excellent example. :)

title: Updated data operator to better handle a join function which returns iden
body:
Updated data operator to better handle a join function which returns identical
values for multiple members of the data array.

For example, if a data array/join function is assigned such that the key value
"A" is returned 3 times, initially we would expect to see 3 corresponding
values in the returned entering selection -- as before.  However, if we again
pass the same data array/join function, we would expect to see no values in the
entering or exiting selections since the data and join are identical to what is
already in place.  However, the previous implementation would show values
exiting.  With this modification, if a given key is returned by the join
function n times, while the previous array had n0 occurrences of the same key,
then n0 corresponding entries will go in the updating selection, and n-n0 will
go to the entering or exiting selection depending on whether duplicates were
added or removed.

title: Better mousewheel precision.
body:
Copy Mike's new mousewheel hack from Polymaps.

Fixes #156.

title: Fixes for d3.min and d3.max.
body: See #161 and #162.

title: Remove extraneous parentheses from `new` operator.
body: Err, yeah. Feel free to ignore this one if you think it makes the code less readable :-)

title: Add d3.zip.
body:
Analagous to Python's built-in `zip()`: http://docs.python.org/library/functions.html#zip

Fixes #145.
